Area of Research:
Theoretical Physics, with emphasis on either Condensed Matter Physics, Optics, and/or Quantum Computing (also, theoretical studies on solar energy).

We perform research in theoretical condensed matter physics, including quantum information processing, computational physics, transport phenomena (e.g., of vortices, electrons and grains), energy conversion and solar energy, as well as the dynamics of complex systems. Our research work is interdisciplinary and also explores the interface between atomic physics, quantum optics, nano-science, and computing. We are also studying open quantum systems, quantum phase transitions, artificial photosynthesis, light-to-electricity conversion, nano-mechanics, hybrid quantum electro-mechanical systems, quantum nano-electronics, and quantum emulators. Particular emphasis is being placed on superconducting Josephson-junction qubits, scalable quantum circuitry and improved designs for their quantum control. We are also studying: spin-orbit interactions; optical angular momentum; wave propagation, localization, and scattering in inhomogeneous and random media; dynamics of spins and vortices in external fields; quantum weak measurements, relativistic wave equations; electron vortices; plasmonics and metamaterials; coupling and resonances. An underlying theme of our work is to better understand nano-scale quantum systems and devise methods to control them. We use physical models to make predictions that can be tested experimentally and that can be used to better understand the observed phenomena.
Our publications are available online at : http://DML.riken.jp/publications.php
See also: http://www.riken.jp/en/research/labs/cems/qtm_inf_electron/qtm_condens_matter/
